title: AI-assisted Data Cleaning Workflow
text:
This site documents a reproducible, AI-assisted workflow for public health data analysis with R.



AI-assisted code generation
Data cleaning and validation, Variable labeling and reference categories
Exporting data for R, SPSS, and Stata


‚ö†Ô∏è This is a template document.








R is the core statistical computing environment used for data cleaning and analysis.
Visit the Comprehensive R Archive Network (CRAN): https://cran.r-project.org
Download and install R for your operating system:
Windows
macOS
Linux
Accept default installation settings.
After installation, verify R by opening it and running:

version




RStudio is an integrated development environment (IDE) that makes working with R scripts, projects, and Quarto documents easier.
Download RStudio Desktop (Free version): https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/
Install RStudio after R is installed.
Open RStudio and confirm it detects your R installation.



Run the following once inside RStudio:

install.packages(c(
  "dplyr",
  "janitor",
  "skimr",
  "jsonlite",
  "ellmer",
  "haven",
  "labelled",
  "rio",
  "ollama"
))

Installing a Local LLM (Offline & Hospital-Safe)
For environments where cloud-based AI tools are restricted (e.g., hospitals, government institutions), a local large language model (LLM) can be used. This workflow supports Ollama, which runs entirely offline.



Download Ollama from: https://ollama.com
Install Ollama for your operating system (Windows / macOS / Linux).
After installation, verify Ollama is running by opening a terminal and typing:
ollama ‚Äìversion



Gemma is a lightweight, open-source model suitable for structured code generation tasks.
In your system terminal, run:

ollama run codegemma

(You may also use larger variants if system resources permit.)
Verify Ollama + Gemma in R
Once Ollama is running in the background, test the connection from R:

library(ellmer)
library(ollama)

model <- chat_ollama(
  model = "codegemma"
)

chat(model, "Respond with: Ollama is working")

If successful, the model will return a short confirmation message.

title: AI-assisted Data Cleaning Workflow
text:
2.1 AI data cleaning

2.1.1 Statement to be added in methodology
‚ÄúAI-assisted code generation was used for data cleaning, with all scripts reviewed and executed by the investigators.‚Äù
Always de-identify before sending to AI


2.1.2 Load and summary for AI

library(dplyr)
library(janitor)
library(skimr)
library(jsonlite)

df <- read.csv("data.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
df <- clean_names(df)

data_summary <- list(
  structure = str(df),
  missing_pct = round(colMeans(is.na(df)) * 100, 2),
  unique_character_values = df |> 
    select(where(is.character)) |> 
    summarise(across(everything(), ~ paste(unique(.), collapse = ", "))),
  numeric_ranges = df |> 
    select(where(is.numeric)) |> 
    summarise(across(everything(), ~ paste(range(., na.rm = TRUE), collapse = "‚Äì")))
)

summary_text <- toJSON(data_summary, pretty = TRUE)

title: AI-assisted Data Cleaning Workflow
text:
2.2 Setup model and api key

2.2.1 OpenAI

SSys.setenv(OPENAI_API_KEY = "paste_api_key")

library(ellmer)

ai_generate_cleaning_code <- function(summary_text, model) {

  prompt <- paste0(
    "You are a public health data analyst.\n\n",
    "INSTRUCTIONS:\n",
    "- Generate ONLY executable R code\n",
    "- No explanations outside code\n",
    "- Do NOT load libraries\n",
    "- Do NOT delete rows\n",
    "- Do NOT impute values\n",
    "- Do NOT change outcome definitions\n",
    "- Include comments in the R code\n\n",
    "TASKS:\n",
    "- Trim whitespace in character variables\n",
    "- Standardize categorical labels\n",
    "- Convert variables to appropriate types\n",
    "- Flag impossible numeric values\n",
    "- Create missingness flags (not imputation)\n\n",
    "DATA SUMMARY:\n",
    summary_text
  )

  response <- model$chat(prompt)
  response$content
}

response <- chat_openai(
  model = "gpt-4.1-mini",
  params = list(temperature = 0.1)
)$chat(prompt)

cleaning_code <- response$content

cat(cleaning_code)



2.2.2 Local LLM (offline, hospital-safe)
No need API for local llm

library(ollamar)
library(jsonlite)

ai_generate_cleaning_code <- function(summary_text,
                                      model_name = "codegemma") {
  
  messages <- list(
    list(
      role = "user",
      content = paste0(
        "INSTRUCTIONS:
- Generate ONLY executable R code
- No explanations outside code
- Do NOT load libraries
- Do NOT delete rows
- Do NOT impute values
- Do NOT change outcome definitions
- Include comments in the R code

TASKS:
- Trim whitespace in character variables
- Standardize categorical labels
- Convert variables to appropriate types
- Flag impossible numeric values
- Create missingness flags (not imputation)

DATA SUMMARY:
", summary_text
      )
    )
  )
  
  resp <- ollamar::chat(
    model = model_name,
    messages = messages
  )
  
  json <- jsonlite::fromJSON(rawToChar(resp$body))
  code <- json$message$content
  
  if (is.null(code) || code == "") {
    stop("Model returned empty content")
  }

  code <- gsub("^```[rR]?\\s*|```$", "", code)
  
  code
}

cleaning_code <- ai_generate_cleaning_code(summary_text)

cat(cleaning_code)



2.2.3 Execute after Review

eval(parse(text = cleaning_code))

title: AI-assisted Data Cleaning Workflow
section: 2.3 AI data typing + labels + reference categories
text:
2.3 AI data typing + labels + reference categories
MENTION THIS IN METHODS (recommended)
‚ÄúAI-assisted code generation was used to standardize variable types, labels, and reference categories. All code was reviewed and executed by the investigators.‚Äù

2.3.1 Load function

library(ollamar)
library(jsonlite)

ai_generate_typing_and_labels_code <- function(summary_text,
                                               model_name = "codegemma") {
  
  prompt <- paste0(
"You are a senior public health biostatistician and R instructor.

TASK:
Generate ONLY executable R code (no explanations outside code).

AUDIENCE:
Public health beginners (MBBS / MPH / MD Community Medicine).

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Ensure correct data types:
   - numeric ‚Üí as.numeric
   - categorical ‚Üí factor
2. Add VARIABLE LABELS (column descriptions)
3. Add VALUE LABELS for categorical variables
4. Explicitly set REFERENCE CATEGORIES using relevel()
5. Comment clearly why each reference category is chosen
6. Do NOT delete rows
7. Do NOT impute missing values
8. Do NOT load libraries
9. Assume dataframe name is `df`

REFERENCE CATEGORY RULES:
- Sex ‚Üí reference = \"Male\"
- Binary exposure ‚Üí reference = \"No\" / \"Unexposed\"
- Education ‚Üí lowest level
- Socioeconomic status ‚Üí lowest class
- Outcome variables ‚Üí DO NOT relevel

OUTPUT:
Return ONLY R code with clear comments.

DATA SUMMARY:
", summary_text
  )
  
  messages <- list(
    list(role = "user", content = prompt)
  )
  
  resp <- ollamar::chat(
    model = model_name,
    messages = messages
  )
  
  json <- jsonlite::fromJSON(rawToChar(resp$body))
  code <- json$message$content
  
  if (is.null(code) || code == "") {
    stop("Model returned empty content")
  }
  
  # Strip markdown fences if present
  code <- gsub("^```[rR]?\\s*|```$", "", code)
  
  code
}



2.3.2 Generate the code

typing_label_code <- ai_generate_typing_and_labels_code(summary_text)

cat(typing_label_code)



2.3.3 Execute code AFTER review

eval(parse(text = typing_label_code))

title: AI-assisted Data Cleaning Workflow
text:
3.1 Data inspection

3.1.1 Load libraries

library(dplyr)
library(janitor)
library(skimr)



3.1.2 Load data

df <- read.csv("data.csv", stringsAsFactors = FALSE)



3.1.3 Inspect

dim(df); names(df); str(df); summary(df)



3.1.4 Clean names

df <- clean_names(df)



3.1.5 Explore

skim(df)



3.1.6 Unique values

df |> select(where(is.character)) |> lapply(unique)



3.1.7 Missingness

colMeans(is.na(df)) * 100



3.1.8 Validate

table(df$sex)
range(df$age, na.rm = TRUE)

title: AI-assisted Data Cleaning Workflow
text:
3.2 Data typing + labels + reference categories (Sample)

# Ensure age is numeric
df <- df |>
  mutate(age = as.numeric(age))

# Convert sex to factor and set reference category
# Reference = Male (standard epidemiologic practice)
df <- df |>
  mutate(
    sex = factor(sex, levels = c("Male", "Female")),
    sex = relevel(sex, ref = "Male")
  )

# Convert smoking status to factor
# Reference = No (unexposed group)
df <- df |>
  mutate(
    smoking = factor(smoking, levels = c("No", "Yes")),
    smoking = relevel(smoking, ref = "No")
  )

# Education level (reference = lowest education)
df <- df |>
  mutate(
    education = factor(
      education,
      levels = c("No formal education", "Primary", "Secondary", "Higher")
    ),
    education = relevel(education, ref = "No formal education")
  )

# Add variable labels (for tables and reports)
attr(df$age, "label") <- "Age in completed years"
attr(df$sex, "label") <- "Sex of the participant"
attr(df$smoking, "label") <- "Current smoking status"
attr(df$education, "label") <- "Highest educational attainment"

title: Epipulse Public Health Data Analysis
text:
Epi-Pulse is a public health‚Äìfocused non-governmental organization dedicated to strengthening population health through epidemiological intelligence, community engagement, and evidence-based interventions. We work at the intersection of research, policy, and practice to translate data into meaningful public health action.
Rooted in the principles of equity, prevention, and scientific rigor, Epi-Pulse aims to respond to emerging and persistent public health challenges with speed, integrity, and impact.




To build healthier, resilient, and equitable communities by transforming epidemiological evidence into sustainable public health action.





To generate and translate high-quality public health evidence for informed decision-making
To strengthen community-based prevention and health promotion initiatives
To support public health systems through research, training, and technical assistance
To promote equity, ethics, and One Health approaches in public health practice





Epi-Pulse aims to:

Conduct epidemiological and public health research addressing priority health issues
Support disease surveillance, outbreak investigation, and health systems strengthening
Promote preventive, promotive, and primary health care interventions
Build capacity among students, health professionals, and community stakeholders
Advocate for evidence-based public health policies and ethical research practices
Integrate One Health, environmental, and occupational health perspectives into public health action





Our work spans multiple domains of public health, including:

Health Education & Capacity Building Training programs, workshops, student mentorship, and public health advocacy
Non-Communicable Diseases (NCDs) Research and interventions related to diabetes, hypertension, nutrition, and lifestyle diseases
Maternal, Child & Adolescent Health Community-based programs, nutrition assessments, and school health initiatives
Environmental & Occupational Health Impact of air quality, workplace exposures, and climate factors on health
One Health & Emerging Infections Integrated approaches linking human, animal, and environmental health
Epidemiology & Surveillance Disease surveillance, outbreak investigations, and data-driven risk assessments





Epi-Pulse was conceptualized in [Year] and formally established in [Month, Year] in response to the growing need for agile, evidence-driven public health organizations in India.





Legal Status: Registered Non-Governmental Organization
Registration Act: [Section 8 Company]
Registration Number: [To be updated]
Place of Registration: [City, State, Country]







Dr.¬†[Name] Qualifications: [MBBS / MD / MPH / PhD ‚Äì as applicable] Expertise: Public Health, Epidemiology, [Key areas]
The Director provides strategic leadership, oversees research and programs, and represents Epi-Pulse in academic, governmental, and community platforms.




Epi-Pulse is supported by a multidisciplinary team of public health professionals, researchers, clinicians, and community advocates.
Core Team Includes:

Epidemiologists
Public Health Researchers
Medical Professionals
Data Analysts & GIS Specialists
Field Coordinators & Program Officers

(Individual member profiles can be added as separate pages if needed.)






Scientific Integrity ‚Äì Evidence before opinion
Equity & Ethics ‚Äì Health for all, without discrimination
Collaboration ‚Äì Partnerships across sectors and disciplines
Community Engagement ‚Äì People-centered public health
Impact Orientation ‚Äì Research that leads to action





At Epi-Pulse, we believe that timely data, ethical research, and community-driven solutions are the heartbeat of effective public health. We are committed to strengthening health systems, empowering communities, and shaping healthier futures.
